Award.AbstractNarration:
From the very first steps of symplectic topology in 1980s flexible and rigid methods played important complementary roles, though
with introduction by M. Gromov of the method of holomorphic curves, rigid methods played the dominating role in the development of the subject. However, it became recently feasible, with a number of important recent advances, to push the results on the flexible side almost to the borderline with the rigid side. The research under the current grant pursues the development of rigid and flexible methods in symplectic topology. Most important tasks on the rigid side include: completion of the algebraic foundations of symplectic field theory (SFT), including the relative theory concerning invariants of Legendrian submanifolds, connections with the theory of integrable systems, and further development and extension of Legendrian surgery technique to all SFT invariants with applications to Hamiltonian dynamics, especially to the theory of quasi-states and quasi-morphisms. On the flexible side, the research will be directed towards further development of the theory of flexible Weinstein manifolds, a new class of symplectic manifolds previously discovered by K. Cieliebak, E. Murphy and the PI, as well as the theory of Lagrangian immersions with minimal number of intersection points. Another new subject which should benefit from both, flexible and rigid methods is symplectic pseudo-isotopy theory, a necessary ingredient towards understanding topology of groups of symplectic and contact transformations.


Symplectic topology is at the crossroads of several mathematical disciplines such as low-dimensional, algebraic and geometric topology, Hamiltonian dynamics, algebraic geometry, mathematical theory of mirror symmetry and theory of integrable systems. Its development, and in particular the development of symplectic field theory, significantly changed the face of these areas. The research under the current grant should bring both, the further development of symplectic topological machinery, and in particular of the algebraic formalism of symplectic field theory, as well as new horizons for its applications to dynamics, low-dimensional topology and theory of quantum integrable systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rigid methods which are mainly based on Gromov's theory of holomorphic curves in symplectic manifolds and Floer-homological techniques, dominated the develoment of symplectic topology since its inception. Flexible methods, designed to test the limits of symplectic rigidity  and  pioneered by Gromov in 1970s had only sporadic successes during the last 3 decades. The situation changed as a result of the work on the current project, where several breakthroughs were achieved on the flexible side of symplectic and contact topology. In particular,
- a well known necessary condition for existence of a contact structure on a closed manifold was proved to be sufficient;
- similarly to the known 3-dimensional case, there was defined a dichotomy of contact structures on manifolds of all dimensions into tight and overtwisted, and the overtwisted contact structures were completely classified;
- contrary to a common belief, it was shown that there are no non-trivial lower bounds on the number of self-intersection points of a Lagrangian submanifold, contrasting with the case of bounds on the number of intersections of two different Lagrangians predicted by Arnold conjectures and proven in many cases.
- there were found new constructions of symplectic structures.

The above results were  also applied to the theory of functions of several complex variables, yielding in particular topological classification of rationally and polynomially convex domains.

The work on the project had a broader impact on human resources. Five graduate students worked on this project. Three of them, including a woman, already   completed their PhD dissertations and wrote 5 papers on the problems addressed in the project. The results of the project was a subject of 4 graduate student workshops, which allowed many graduate students and young mathematicians around the US to join the research on the new directions initiated  by the current project.

 


Last Modified: 10/09/2015
Modified by: Yakov Eliashberg
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Rigid methods which are mainly based on Gromov's theory of holomorphic curves in symplectic manifolds and Floer-homological techniques, dominated the develoment of symplectic topology since its inception. Flexible methods, designed to test the limits of symplectic rigidity and pioneered by Gromov in 1970s had only sporadic successes during the last 3 decades. The situation changed as a result of the work on the current project, where several breakthroughs were achieved on the flexible side of symplectic and contact topology. In particular, - a well known necessary condition for existence of a contact structure on a closed manifold was proved to be sufficient; - similarly to the known 3-dimensional case, there was defined a dichotomy of contact structures on manifolds of all dimensions into tight and overtwisted, and the overtwisted contact structures were completely classified; - contrary to a common belief, it was shown that there are no non-trivial lower bounds on the number of self-intersection points of a Lagrangian submanifold, contrasting with the case of bounds on the number of intersections of two different Lagrangians predicted by Arnold conjectures and proven in many cases. - there were found new constructions of symplectic structures. The above results were also applied to the theory of functions of several complex variables, yielding in particular topological classification of rationally and polynomially convex domains. The work on the project had a broader impact on human resources. Five graduate students worked on this project. Three of them, including a woman, already completed their PhD dissertations and wrote 5 papers on the problems addressed in the project. The results of the project was a subject of 4 graduate student workshops, which allowed many graduate students and young mathematicians around the US to join the research on the new directions initiated by the current project.
